title: GE Earnings Unexpectedly Rise, Cash-Flow View Raised; GE Stock Jumps
text:
General Electric (GE) reported a surprise third-quarter earnings gain Wednesday morning as industrial businesses generated solid cash flow. The ailing industrial giant raised its full-year cash flow target. GE stock rose, moving toward a buy point.

X

GE Earnings

Estimates: Analysts expected GE earnings per share to slide 14% to 12 cents, according to Zacks Investment Research.

Results: GE earnings rose slightly to 15 cents a share, excluding many items. That's the first EPS year-over-year gain in seven quarters. Sales dipped 0.1% to $23.36 billion, slightly beating.

Organic orders fell 1%, with backlog up 14% to $386 billion. Revenue fell 14% in the power segment. Revenue rose 8% in aviation, 5% in health and 13% in renewable energy. Those segments will form the core of the "new," post-restructuring GE.

Outlook: General Electric reiterated its recent full-year EPS guidance of 55-65 cents, in line with Wall Street consensus for GE earnings of 60 cents a share. GE now sees industrial cash flow of flat to up $2 billion in 2019, after generating $650 million in Q3, up from a prior view of negative $1 billion to positive $1 billion.

GE Stock: Shares surged 6.5% to 9.66 before the open of Wednesday's stock market trading. GE stock is consolidating with a buy point of 10.89, near a decade-long low. But most of the latest GE stock pattern is below the 200-day line, which is not a great sign.

The relative strength line, measuring a stock's performance against the S&P 500, is at a two-decade low. The RS line is the blue line in the chart provided. Honeywell (HON) and Dow Jones component United Technologies (UTX) were not yet active. Both GE and Honeywell are former Dow Jones stocks.

GE Restructuring

Ahead of the GE earnings report, the flagship aviation unit was in focus amid the Boeing (BA) 737 Max crisis and after Honeywell (HON) and United Technologies (UTX) beat on strong aviation sales. In July, General Electric warned of $1.4 billion in potential costs if 737 Max groundings drag on.

Wall Street also was watching for improvement in GE's power and finance units, cash flow and leverage position, more than a year after former Danaher (DHR) CEO Larry Culp took the helm. Those are areas of special concern to investors as General Electric, which has gutted the once-trusty GE stock dividend, looks for a turnaround.

Under Culp, the industrial giant has made several moves to raise or conserve cash to pay down debt, including selling a majority stake in Baker Hughes (BKR). But GE stock has flattened out after a sharp rally at the start of 2019.

Culp has called improving GE's financial position his No. 1 priority.

description: GE earnings rose in the third quarter as General Electric industrial businesses generated cash. GE stock Wednesday, nearing a buy point in a flawed base.
